title: Seepage and Leakage: What It Means for Wine and Spirits Value
metaTitle: Seepage and Leakage in Wine Bottles | Value Impact | Proof Cellars
metaDescription: What is seepage? Learn why bottles leak, how to identify old vs active leaks, and how it impacts the sellability of your collection.
summary: How to identify seepage and when a bottle is likely disqualified.

sections.heading: Quick Answer
content: Seepage (ullage) is when liquid escapes past the cork or closure. It is a distress signal.
list: It signals the seal has failed.
Air has likely entered, oxidizing the contents.
It significantly devalues the bottle.
Sometimes caused by heat (expansion) or just old cork failure.

sections.heading: Identifying Seepage
content: Look closely at the neck and capsule.
list: Sticky residue under the foil.
Wine stains running down the label.
Crusty sugar deposits around the capsule rim.
Smell of wine/vinegar near the unopened bottle.

sections.heading: Old vs Active Leaks
list: Old Seepage: Dried stain, level is stable. Could be from one event years ago. Still devalues, but might be drinkable.
Active Seepage: Wet, sticky. The bottle is actively failing. Do not ship itâ€”it will leak in transit and ruin others.

sections.heading: Why It Matters
content: Collectors pay for perfection. A leaking bottle is a ticking time bomb.
list: Value Drop: Usually 50% to 100% loss depending on severity.
Risk: We buy risks, but we pay risking pricing.
Spirits: Leaking whiskey closures (often wax or cork) can sometimes be resealed with parafilm (for preservation, not sale), but value is hit.

sections.heading: Common Mistakes
list: Wiping off the stain before taking photos (we will see the low fill level and corroded foil anyway).
Shipping a leaking bottle sideways (it will empty itself in the box).
Ignoring low fill levels.

sections.heading: What to Do Next
list: Stand leaking bottles upright immediately.
Do not lay them down even for storage.
Photograph the leak clearly so we can assess it.
Mark them as 'Leaking/Low Fill' on your list.

faqs.question: Can I re-cork it?
faqs.answer: No. Only the original winery can re-cork, and that is a rare, expensive service (reconditioning). You cannot do it yourself.

faqs.question: What is parafilm?
faqs.answer: A laboratory film used to wrap closures to prevent further evaporation. It is okay to use for storage, but remove it or disclose it before selling.

faqs.question: Do you buy leaking bottles?
faqs.answer: Rarely. If it is a very valuable bottle (e.g., 1945 Mouton), we might buy it as a 'drinker' for a fraction of market price.

faqs.question: What about wax seals?
faqs.answer: Wax often hides seepage. If the wax is stained or sticky, the cork underneath has failed.

faqs.question: Does shipping cause seepage?
faqs.answer: Yes, if the bottle is subjected to heat or extreme pressure changes in a plane. That's why we use insulated shipping.
